segments.text: Just a week later, she made her way to Claude, feeling her knees tremble with every step.
What could she possibly tell him?
She was even more afraid of what she might hear from him.
She climbed the seven steps leading to his office with faltering legs.
And when she arrived, she stood in front of the door, too anxious about what lay ahead to knock.
Finally, she understood she had no choice and reached for the door, knocking three soft knocks.
Yes, a deep voice called from inside the room.
She opened the door and immediately felt herself melt in response to his familiar, warm smile.
Claude stood up to greet her, approached and kissed both her cheeks, first one, then the other.
He was part of the big wave of immigrants from Morocco who had arrived in Ashkelon a decade earlier, bringing with them various cultural customs.
With the French songs and meticulous fashion came the cheek kissing.
But he didn't kiss the cheeks of everyone who came to his office, knowing her for years.
He gestured for her to sit in a chair opposite him.
Again, she felt the fear of the unknown creeping inside her.
There are manners and politeness and there is reality.
But Claude didn't rush.
He looked at her with a scrutinizing gaze and asked,
Are you eating as you should?
Why do they always ask her that?
She does eat and knows how to feed others too, all because she's so slender.
Yes, Claude, I eat properly.
You don't need to worry about me," she said, a hint of impatience in her voice.
Good, just checking," he smiled.
Listen.
The moment she heard that listen, she thought to herself, here it comes.
Yehuda spoke to me and I think it's a really good idea, given that he bought the house as an investment and is not entirely sure what to do with it.
Eventually, he'll probably sell it as four private homes.
But in the meantime, the house just stands there.
And I understand you're living in one of the rooms and sometimes renting out another, keeping the house clean and maintained in the process.
This maintains his asset, and it's a great idea that serves both sides.
Of course, if he suddenly decides to sell or changes his mind, he will give you prior notice.
He fell silent and looked at her with a gentle, somewhat embarrassed gaze, then added, It didn't occur to me that you wouldn't have a place to stay.
Maybe we should have handled this whole sale differently and figured out how to take care of you too.
But your sister's lawyers were so aggressive, almost pushy, just wanting to finish everything a minute after you turned 18.
Now it's too late, but I'm glad Yehuda agrees with this arrangement.
I don't know if he told you, but there's someone willing to stand by you at least until you finish your military service, and in any case for the next two years.
She was choked up before she could open her mouth.
Yehuda muttered something, but I didn't understand why anyone would support me.
Who is it?
I can't say.
It's a secret and will remain so, and please don't talk about it.
I can only assure you he's doing it wholeheartedly.
And if you ask me, it's mainly for Lucy.
He owed her a lot and loved her very much.
Maybe like you, he thinks she's watching from above.
and he wants her to know that her daughter has a place to lay her head and that someone is watering her garden.
Now a smile spread across her face.
The story about watering the garden for mom was well known to many.
Yossi the Postman made sure to tell it to anyone willing to listen, and it would touch the listeners every time anew.
In her mind, Leora began to go through the names of those close to her, thinking maybe one of them was sponsoring her.
always circling back to just one.
It must be him.
He can and misses Lucy so much.
He's always called her my girl.
He had always been like an uncle to her.
But she wouldn't ask and wouldn't spoil the secret.
If it really is him, it reassures her.
Claude opened a drawer and took out a chart filled with amounts shown inside squares for each month.
She looked at him in surprise.
It's very little.
Well, I wanted it to be something you could manage with your military salary.
Let's see how it goes.
And in three months, come visit me again, agreed?
She felt all her tense muscles gradually relax, the ringing in her ears ceased, and the cold that had previously spread through her body thawed and turned into a warm stream of joy.
She stood up and smiled at him.
Don't worry, I won't disappoint you.
I'll pay it each month on time and will come back in three months.
Claude stood in front of her, again kissed her cheek.
But this time also offered his hand for a handshake, giving a business-like seal to the whole situation.
Then, he couldn't help himself and gently stroked her head.
Everything will be okay, you'll see," he said and hurried to sit back behind his desk.

Once she left his office, he sighed and closed his eyes for a moment, leaning back in his chair, trying to recall the first time he arrived at the pink house, about a month after his immigration to Israel.
Music played in the background and people sat around tables and the bar, drinks in their hands.
Lucy approached him and immediately spoke to him in French.
She could identify those immigrants from Morocco who were meticulously dressed, smelled wonderful, and their hair was neatly combed.
Something in their European mannerisms was mingled with a Mediterranean temperament, and she always thought it was a fantastic immigration wave that added a lot of spice to the atmosphere around.
He remembers being surprised by her excellent French, recalling how something in the way she carried herself made him immediately look up to her.
and she had such a wonderful scent.
In Paris, he had only seen such women.
Now thinking about that secret person, he knew deep down that although he had been a close friend of both her and Josef, he had secretly been in love with Lucy all these years.
This man, with all his wealth, businesses and refined attire, was a lonely widower, and Lucy had become over the years his confidant and best friend.
There was nothing he didn't share with her.
He wasn't surprised that he now stepped up to help the girl.
Somehow it wasn't just her who felt Lucy watching from above, having left too early, with too many things unresolved, needing to know they're getting sorted.
And of course, that someone is watering her garden.
A smile appeared once more on his lips.
He opened his eyes, straightened in his chair, rearranged the papers on his desk, ready and prepared to start his workday.
